Over 2000 hours on record here Though technically I've been playing Elite since the mid 80's.

I'm not going to talk about what this game can or cannot do. It's different strokes for different folks. What pleases me may not please you. For that, you have to play it. The most important thing to remember, is this is a simulation, not an arcade. You need to spend some time learning the game, you can't just log in and start blasting.

It is the overall experience which is why I recommend this game.  It really captures the atmosphere. The dev team are increasing their firing rate on new content in recent years, and the game offers you all the freedom you need to take on any space career that you like, from being a passive tour guide, to being a bloodthirsty pirate. You have total freedom.

My biggest plus about the game is the customer service. I have contacted them several times over the years regarding varying issues, and they fixed every problem and granted every request that I had. The stories of other players tell a similar story. If you are nice and polite with them, they are happy to bend some rules and make exceptions where other games would not be so willing to go against their own policies to satisfy a player.

So, is it worth it? To this old space dog - it is.

[h2]The Good[/h2]

The game delivers exactly what it promises: a huge, open galaxy full of meaningful gameplay loops. Whether you want to explore deep space, mine resources, map planets, run cargo, smuggle contraband, or dive into exobiology, thereâ€™s always something to work toward. Ship engineering and upgrades offer plenty of long-term progression, and the new colonisation update adds even more freedom by letting you claim systems and build your own orbital or ground infrastructures.

Space combat is a standout. It has a steep learning curve, but rewards skill and creativity - letting even smaller or weaker ships hold their own if flown well. Most of your time will be spent in space, but landing on airless or thin-atmosphere worlds offers a nice change of pace and access to exclusive resources.

[h2]The Not-So-Good[/h2]

The game includes microtransactions for early access ships, stations, and cosmetic items. They arenâ€™t overly aggressive, and everything except cosmetics can be earned with in-game credits - but itâ€™s still worth noting.

Some systems feel underdeveloped. Powerplay and on-foot gameplay could use more depth, especially for combat, where gunplay and AI behaviour feel dated and inconsistent. Exploration-focused players will get more out of the on-foot side thanks to exobiology being both profitable and satisfying.

Thereâ€™s also a grind. Gaining reputation for bigger ships or collecting engineering materials can take time, even if itâ€™s easier than it used to be. Unlocking engineers still requires a fair amount of prerequisite work.

The gameâ€™s narrative side shines with long-running mysteries and slow-burn story arcs that often lead to massive events like alien wars or uncovering decades-old conspiracies. Theyâ€™re fantastic when they hit, but progress can be very slow - weeks may pass between major developments so do be prepared to wait.


I'd absolutely recommend Elite Dangerous because it constantly gives you something to chase, something to discover, and there's always something to master - itâ€™s a game that genuinely rewards your time more often than not.

Elite Dangerous is kind of a handful, I personally love it, it's something I've played for years, perhaps not consistently, but still adore. I guess the way I could picture it is like a really good comfort food that you know is probably not good for you but you'll eat anyways, or like cigarettes, or both.

This game is really really pretty, it's sound design, atmosphere and graphics are really solid, all the ships have unique engine sounds and characteristics that drive someone like me to want to try all of them out, at least for a little while. All the systems are fairly in-depth, not enough to scare off a person just jumping in, but enough to be engaging, most of the time. Honestly it's fairly versatile, when you're finally well off enough to kind of go for whatever you can do whatever you want, combat if you want more engaging gameplay, exploration for a mix of engagement and lax gameplay, and mining and trading for something you kind of just turn your brain off for or as a stimulus to stay focused on other things like D&D or some other form of media. The good part is now there's a lot of ways to make good money, and you don't really need to like cheat the system or anything anymore to make enough money to be worth your time and effort. 

This game is very far from perfect though, it kind of lacks a lot still and has seen a long period of inactivity that has only recently been dusted off and has been getting more and more content. It also kind of sucks how FDev isn't exactly great in it's monetization philosophy, either, it's a microtransaction game which it doesn't lock anything out per-se (and we should keep it that way, pretty please, fdev) but it does keep non-paying customers waiting for a few months for the 'early-access' period of content to be rolled out to them. I think obviously they have a lot of people who are really passionate about this game but also some who are kind of greedy, or otherwise need to keep these systems in place either due to necessity for funds or legal reasons, it isn't right, but it's the situation that the game is in.

Gameplay wise, the Odyssey Expansion is hit or miss, Exobiology and the exploration aspect of the game is emphasized a lot more and is pretty fun, as is the scavenging and salvage. The gunplay kind of leaves a lot to be desired, however, where it feels kind of weak and the guns don't sound very satisfying or don't really reflect how powerful they are stat-wise, which feels very odd considering how excellent the sound design is in other parts of the game. They claim to be working on the gunplay balance in the future, so we'll see if that improves at all in due time.

Overall, the game is an imperfect- but solid title, I'd recommend just buying it on sale, even though 24 bucks is honestly pretty fair. You can get a lot of mileage out of it just so long as you kind of cycle through the different 'professions' for lack of a better term so as not to get burnt out.

This game is the real Star Citizen. If only ED had the same budget as SC... the possibilities would be limitless. But as it is, this game is an amazing accomplishment, and insanely underrated. It has to be the single greatest spaceflight simulator of all time, as well as one of the greatest science fiction MMOs of all time. The only game that really overshadows it is, of course, the one and only Eve Online. 

Elite is essentially like No Man's Sky, except the spaceflight, combat, and ship customization are actually good, whereas No Man's Sky is sadly mediocre and as deep as a puddle of piss. NMS is basically a pretty looking tech demo, but ED is a true sandbox. I don't mean to hate on NMS, but for me the game has simply fallen short on what I want from this type of game, regardless of how much it improved over the years.

Basically, No Man's Sky leaves you wanting more, and it lacks any kind of depth, or meaningful progression. It's very surface level.

On the other hand, Star Citizen promises a whole lot, but ultimately hasn't delivered, and it's not really a stable, finished product, AND the system requirements to play it are fairly prohibitive - you can play Elite on a toaster, but Star Citizen requires a monster machine to actually run, and even then it's still full of bugs.

Essentially, I see Elite Dangerous as the black horse of these three games - not nearly as flashy or overhyped the way the other two are, yet in many ways a perfect balance of what both the other two games want to be. 

I hope the game sees a brighter future, because it really deserves it.

Elite: Dangerous is such a fascinating game.

Nowhere else have I seen such a dedicated and hard-working community coupled with such a terrible and lazy developer.

10 years of Elite with countless community tools, out of game groups and networking, dedicated information gathering software all to provide a QOL to the players that the devs have never even attempted to provide.

Bugs take years to get fixed (if ever), the pace of updates is a new ship every few months with almost no gameplay differences (This is the most active the game has ever been), and a development team that is so wildly out of touch from the community I can only assume they're locked in Frontier's basement. 

We've reached a point in the community where every single greedy action by the devs is brushed off as "Oh they need to keep the servers on" as if this isn't a full priced game with required dlc (That you need if you ever want to meet another player or use the new ships) and thousands of dollars worth of cosmetics.

That is just the overall view of the game, a more detailed explanation of why everyone is bothering to make their negative review is as follows:

For the past year, frontier have been slowly developing colony building into the game, which the community accepted with eager arms despite how unfinished and half-baked it was. Almost no explanation was given to how anything worked, bugs were constantly present, and the entire gameplay loop was more unrewarding material transport (something already part of the game) for dozens of hours. Despite that, hundreds of people have colonised thousands of systems, gathering groups and communities together to FINALLY make a mark on the game. People have quickly realised that half of the "stats" given in-game are worthless, tons of features are missing. and the entire thing had little to no purpose other than essentially map painting.

An entire year later, and colonisation is ready to come out of beta! Almost completely identical but with new QOL! Like the ability to deconstruct your buildings (not possible for the longest time) and slightly more logically modifiers to how the space stations run. Realistically? Colonisation is still only because you want to leave a mark on the game, a tiny insignificant mark that will take you hundreds of hours of the most boring kind of gameplay. 

Now, Frontier have come up with a brilliant idea to really tie off and celebrate the end of their "immense" work on colonisation, a $30 voucher to place a station from the original elite into one of your systems. It has the added benefit of skipping the 100+ hours that you would need to construct it manually. Once, of course. If you ever want to build a 2nd one you'll have to go through the whole agonising process again. 

So the community, the disgusting cheapskates who only paid for the full game + dlc, ask Frontier "Hey, will we ever be able to grind for 100+ hours to build one of these ourselves?" 

Frontier, in their infinite wisdom, said no, of course not, "why would you deserve anything, purchaser and active community member of our game?"

It was only after days of the community yelling and complaining that Frontier finally relented. "Fine, you can buy it now, or wait to build it in 2-4 months time, like we do with every new ship."

Except, JUST as everyone was ready to put it all aside, and forgive Frontier again for a controversy that would decimate a less-dedicated game's community, they released a final patch for colonisation. Was it filled with an actual guide? An explanation for what the hell all the stats actually do? New buildings? QOL? Anything?

"No lol, remember that first shitty space station you built in your system? The one that you have a time limit to build, forcing you to play 100 hours of the most mind-numbing actions in a month? This will update all the systems you built over the past year retroactively." "Btw we're releasing the new station now and Oh look at that it has the best stats you really should just buy it and save yourself the hassle of playing the gameloop we designed."

It's amazing how Frontier can treat the community like pigs on a farm, feeding them crumbs of gameplay every few months and expecting nothing but money to flow into their wallets.

The community is so dedicated to this game despite how terribly the devs treat them, to the point where they somehow feel responsibility to BUY useless cosmetics just to keep the servers running, as if any of that is their responsibility.

I personally have such love for the game and the people in it, and yet such loathing towards whoever is in charge of the direction this game is going in, my 778 hours are 70% boring mindless gameplay, 20% doing something that actively goes against the game design, and 10% actually appreciating whatever Frontier has made that year.

Elite Dangerous is a hugely mixed bag. This review focuses, in order, on money to value, activities, UI, and external tools. 

I got the game on sale for $2.50, and I got my value out of that for sure, even $20 would still be pretty good in my opinion, if not for the above. There are many activities such as mining, exploring, missions, as well as ground content & biology (with Odyssey), trading, faction influencing (minor powers and powers), combat, and improvements on your ships via buying better modules and upgrading via engineering. There is likely to be something you really enjoy about this game, and hopefully many things you enjoy! There are also options to play with only friends, and not interact with other players, if that's your style, and you can opt into playing in public at any time you want, or completely. 

With that said, I cannot write a review without talking about the UI. It's an absolute nightmare, and has huge failures in terms of ease of accessibility and efficiency. It's so badly done that it gets in the way of having fun, of focusing on the game itself rather than a menu telling you about details.  There is way too much to say about it in the worst way, and everything about it wastes a massive amount of time collectively, and can be plain irksome. Just talking about the navigation tab alone: It's sorted exclusively by distance, there are no subcategories outside of a filter, which also mixes them / doesn't provide a way to sort first by station, then by points of interest, for example. Since they're exclusively sorted by distance, and since you're often moving in space, the listings can change, and move your current selection up or down, as well as the thing you want to select up and down, and can constantly keep doing so. Filtering is the best answer to this, but you can't divide sections by filter. You can't stop the listings from moving or "freeze" the listings, and you can't pin favorites to the top for quick access to what you want. The UI in general is beyond a failure in my view. It has a lot of features, but it seems like feature creep happened where more and more was added to the game over time, and the system now is beyond the point where it's anywhere close to good. Can you do what you want to do? Usually. There is almost always a way to do something, but it may be unefficient on many different levels. Honestly, the UI alone is a completely valid reason to not recommend this game to other players, it's truly atrocious. 

The other major negative to bring up is that the design of the game is outdated in aspects, such that external tools, such as Inara, are constantly brought up to solve many issues present in the game. While I support external tools, love and appreciate the work put into them, the massive amount of features the various sites dedicated to Elite Dangerous provide really indicates how huge the issues that the game has are.
